title: MPs back Boris Johnson’s legislative plans
text:
MPs backed the list of laws he proposed last week by Boris Johnson | Chris J Ratcliffe/Getty Images MPs back Boris Johnson’s legislative plans UK prime minister says plans offer ‘a new age of opportunity for the whole country.’

LONDON — Boris Johnson was handed a boost Thursday when MPs backed the list of laws he proposed last week.

The House of Commons voted 310 to 294 to support the government’s legislative program, known as the queen’s speech because the monarch reads it out during a special ceremony.

The result has no legal weight but — like the vote for his Brexit deal on Tuesday — it shows Johnson can unite his party alongside Northern Ireland's Democratic Unionist Party, which props up his minority government, despite not having an outright majority of his own.

But the U.K. prime minister will be unable to address many of his domestic plans until he has delivered on Brexit.

His proposed timetable for passing Brexit legislation was rejected by MPs on Tuesday. Shortly before the vote on Thursday, Johnson revealed he would give MPs more time to scrutinize his Brexit legislation if they vote for a general election on Monday.

His legislative plans included bills to deliver Brexit and forge a new relationship with the EU, increase sentencing for serious crimes and overhaul the rail network. Plans to crack down on drone use, boost environmental protections and make voters show photo ID before they cast their ballots were also included.

After he unveiled the 26 proposed bills last Monday, Johnson said the plans offer “a new age of opportunity for the whole country.”

But opposition Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn said: “The prime minister promised that this queen's speech would dazzle us. On closer inspection, it is nothing more than fool's gold.”
description: UK prime minister says plans offer ‘a new age of opportunity for the whole country.’
